name: Murray, Sen Andrew
text:
—I move:
(11)	 Schedule 1, item 4, page 84 (line 4), omit "21", substitute "28".
This amendment relates to whether the notice of meetings should be 21 days or 28 days. We commend the government's decision to increase it from 14 to 21; now the battle is whether it should be 28.
There has been a long battle between those with a managerial philosophy who want decision making facilitated and those with a shareholder perspective who want time to consider the impact of board and management recommendations. Quite frankly, there are arguments on both sides, as the parliamentary secretary knows well.
As a general rule, one would expect that, in any conflict between the two, it is investors and owners whose views should carry greater weight. The majority report summarised the arguments concerning section 249HL of the bill, which raised the required notice to be given for meetings from 14 to 21 days. The joint committee had previously recommended 28 days, which is an important point to note. Shareholder and investor groups continue to support the 28 days approach and the Australian Democrats see no reason to vary their support for 28 days.

name: Campbell, Sen Ian
text:
—I think Senator Murray is quite right: there is a debate about this matter. When I first had to turn my mind to it, I had a number of conflicting views put to me. Some managers and directors are not overly opposed to 28 days because there are benefits in some respects. But a number of shareholders and shareholder groups are opposed to 28 days if they are trying to take 
 action against a company and against directors and are trying to get something resolved. For example, if control of a company has passed and a group of dissident directors are quickly trying to organise an extraordinary general meeting, they want to move quickly. I know that, even under the current law, some groups of directors who have approached me believe that it is very hard to take action against directors who they believe are acting against the interests of shareholders.
So if shareholders who believe that directors are acting against the interests of the company want to call an extraordinary general meeting, they have to go through the process of getting together enough minority shareholders to petition for an extraordinary general meeting and then have to wait 14 days. I think it is 14 days, but for the sake of the argument it does not really matter. The argument is that this is not a provision that is protecting directors from a meeting and that shorter periods are better for directors. Shorter periods are, for many minority shareholders, not a bad idea. They allow them to take action and get that action.
I know that Senator Murray and people like Shann Turnbull—who try to promote shareholder activism, as I and the government do—would see that having to wait 28 days to have an extraordinary general meeting because of this new notice provision would be an eternity. I would like to put to bed the argument that having long notice periods is pro-shareholders and directors are opposed to it because it hurts them. Long notice periods can be quite harmful to shareholders trying to take action.
The main source of support for 28 days is actually international funds. The push comes from people in Florida, and I am not saying this in a derogatory, xenophobic way. It comes from large international fund managers who would prefer to have 28 days because they are further away. I have put it to them—my friends from Florida, San Francisco and other places—that, with modern telecommunications and with the facilitation of electronic commerce that is in this bill and in the CLERP bills, the requirement for it is reducing as time goes by; it is not increasing.
As with a number of these other matters, this does deserve further focus. Again, this was one of the amendments that was supported by the joint parliamentary committee in its initial inquiry. As you say, Senator Murray, the existing requirement is for 14 days. The government has extended it to 21 days. We thought that for the domestic mums and dads—which is the cliche of the 1990s—the mum and dad investors, who are the great bulk of shareholders in Australia, and even for institutions in Australia, so Australian institutional investors, 21 days is a 33 per cent increase on what they have at the moment. It is a long time for an institution, with all of their expert advisers on these matters, to make up its mind about how it is going to vote at an EGM or an AGM.
But really the benefit you are trying to deliver is to foreign shareholders, and that is where I struck the balance. Twenty-one days is what we regard as a nice balance. Again, it is not something that I would seek to die in a ditch about or fight for the rest of my political life about. The government will oppose this. This is not one of the ones that we regard as a bit here or there. We do think that moving out to 28 days is quite a significant change: you are doubling the notice period. It is quite a significant change. The government at this stage remains opposed to 28 days.
What I am prepared to say, however, is that I would be very pleased to see a bigger debate amongst the general corporate law community about 21 days versus 28 days. I have really not seen a lot of argument that favours 28 days. As for shareholder groups like the ACA and the Australian Shareholders Association, you cannot strongly oppose something like 28 days versus 21, but I know that the push for this comes from overseas because they want a bit of extra time in which to consider these things. That is a legitimate concern.
When I try to balance these things, my general approach is to weight it in favour of the great bulk of shareholders in Australia and Australian institutions, who are not really worked up about whether it is 21 days or 28.
There is a downside, Senator Murray, as you have suggested. The downside is it takes longer to get things done. I will reassert for the third time that it is a detriment to small shareholders who are trying to take action against directors who they believe are not acting in the interests of the shareholders. A case I have had put before me at least half a dozen times in Western Australia while I have been in this portfolio has been where a hundred shareholders want to get together and call an EGM because they think the directors are selling off company assets.
Small shareholders come to me saying, `We are trying to get this EGM together; we want to stop these directors selling this mine'—or prospect or whatever—`but they are going to flog it off to someone else before we get to the EGM. Once we get to the EGM it is too late.' This is in a 14 day scenario. They have to get their petition together and organise the EGM and in the meantime these directors, they believe, are acting in this way. Longer notice periods can be to the significant detriment of small shareholders. I think we have found a balance. I am convinced about it, but it is something that could constructively be considered by the committee of which you are a member.

name: Murray, Sen Andrew
text:
—Parliamentary Secretary, you do indeed put the case very well, because there genuinely is an alternative case. For the assistance of the committee I will quote from the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities' November 1996 unanimous recommendation. This is what they said on notice of meetings:
The bill proposes to increase the general notice period from the current 14 days to 21 days. Arguments were put that the period ought to be further extended to 28 days to enable overseas investors to cast a more fully informed vote. A 28-day notice period would seem to involve little additional inconvenience for the management of listed companies while providing shareholders, particularly foreign investors who, it was suggested, now own or manage 60 per cent of Australian equities, with a more realistic period of time to arrange for the casting of their votes.
Senator Campbell properly puts the alternative argument. We heard this debate again at the 
 second committee hearing in March. I thought it appropriate therefore to put it before the Senate as an issue of concern in view of the substantial number of significant public companies which are foreign owned and which have such a material impact on our stock exchange and our society. I would be interested to hear the views of the opposition.

name: Cook, Sen Peter
text:
—Let me accommodate Senator Murray and, hopefully, the chamber with the opposition's views. In my speech in the second reading debate I emphasised that I thought the 28 day period was the appropriate period and referred to the unanimous cross-party recommendation of the original joint parliamentary committee review, to which Senator Andrew Murray has now referred. I also drew attention to the fact that the decision of the government to limit the time to 21 days has been criticised. You are right. My advice is that international investors are the source of that criticism. Looking at the world's major capital markets, the United States has a 30 day period, Germany has a 32 day period and France has a 30 day period.
It is also my understanding that Dr Stephen Davis, the president of Davis Global Advisors of Newton, Massachusetts, wrote to you, Parliamentary Secretary, suggesting that, if the bill was passed in its present form, this measure would set Australia on a course that would place it behind the emerging international best practice of 28 to 30 days. That is where we are coming from.
That seems to be a fairly reasonable amount of references to the time period. I do bear in mind the things that you have said. They are important. The question of shareholder control of companies is fundamental to our philosophy on this, and activist shareholders is pretty much the desired state of affairs. It is a question of whether the exception should make the rule or whether there are exceptions to a general rule that it is desirable to adopt. For those reasons, we will support the Democrat amendment.

		 (a)	 at least 2 weeks but no more than 4 weeks before the next annual general meeting held after the commencement of this section, or at the second annual general meeting after commencement if there is insufficient time between commencement and the next annual general meeting, circulate a summary of the method of electing directors which is described in this Division, together with the opinion of its directors on matters relevant to the application of this method to the company; and
		 (b)	 propose a resolution, at the next or second annual general meeting held after the commencement of this section (as the case may be), that the company elects that this Division apply to it. 

	 (3)	 Any resolution of a listed corporation which would result in this Division no longer applying to the company is invalid.
	 (4)	 Nothing in this Division requires a company which was a listed corporation at the commencement of this section to propose a resolution at any annual general meeting, other than the next annual general meeting held after the commencement of this section, that this Division apply to the company, if the resolution under paragraph (2)(b) is defeated.
250V  Directors to be elected annually
	 (1)	 All directorships of a company become vacant at the annual general meeting of that company.
	 (2)	 The time at which directorships become vacant is immediately before the meeting proceeds to elect directors.
	 (3)	 Unless precluded by the company's constitution, a person who has previously held a directorship of the company may nominate for re-election.
250W  Process of election
	 (1)	 The election of directors must be conducted by a poll.
	 (2)	 Each member of the company is entitled to the number of votes calculated using the following formula:
		 V x S
		 where:
 V  is the number of directorship vacancies.
 S  is the number of shares held by the member.
	 (3)	 Members may cast their votes as they think fit in favour of any number of the nominees for directorships and members need not cast all of their votes.
Democrat amendment No. 25 refers to the election of directors. I will briefly put the case, if I may. The existing method of electing company directors on a limited re-election pattern has been severely criticised for being undemocratic and unrepresentative and for denying the appropriate representation of minority interests. The current system of electing directors facilitates the dominance of control groups and lessens the possibility of support being expressed for particular directors. The result of this is that, for minority interests to be held, minorities must often rely on expensive and problematic remedies such as recourse to the legal system, the ASX rules 
 and ASIC which reduces the attractiveness of investing, reduces genuine shareholder participation and facilitates fairly domineering managerial or board control.
In order to avoid this situation, Shann Turnbull, who has been referred to before in this debate, and others propose a system of preferential voting, also described as cumulative voting, in listed companies for the election of directors in which all directors would be elected annually with each share obtaining as many votes as there are vacancies. In the United States this procedure is mandated as best practice by federal law for banks and for corporations in some states.
To mandate this type of preferential voting for directors of listed companies the law would need to specify that the number of directors to be elected will be determined by the company's constitution, all directors would retire each year, each share will obtain as many votes as there were board vacancies and each shareholder could distribute as they thought fit all or some of the votes available to them from their shareholding to any number of those nominated as directors. The consequence of this optional preferential method is that shareholders can ascribe their votes to indicate their preference for a director or directors.
Although the Australian Democrats believe that this system is desirable for all listed companies, we appreciate it may not be appropriate to require existing companies to change their constitutions. Accordingly, this recommendation applies to only newly listed companies, which we suggest should adopt this system. We also suggest that existing listed companies should be required to allow their shareholders to assess the new system and to vote on whether they wish to convert to it.
This is another part of our governance proposals. This concerns a democratisation of companies. We believe this advances the corporate governance envelope. I anticipate the parliamentary secretary's response and I suggest to him, in view of his likely response, that, if this suggestion goes down, it could be referred to the committee as an appropriate matter to be considered and, what is more, 
 considered with your blessing, not necessarily your support, but certainly your view that it should be viewed with concern.

name: Campbell, Sen Ian
text:
—As I understand it, we are dealing with amendments Nos 35 to 39 and amendment No. 41. Amendments Nos 35 and 36 are to do with foreign disclosure. These are matters I referred to in my closing of the second reading debate. They do add significant compliance costs to companies, but, most importantly, as I said in that speech, they do throw away sovereignty from Australia. Basically, if the SEC says `Thou shalt do this,' to the handful of Australian companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange—roughly 2,000 or thereabouts—then they would be required to report to their shareholders in Australia, information which may be entirely irrelevant to their shareholders.
The reality is that the information that is required to be placed before shareholders on a foreign bourse is usually readily available thorough their databases. Certainly the information that is required to be disclosed to the 
 New York Stock Exchange and to the SEC in the United States is available to anyone who wants to access it via the New York Stock Exchange's database—which has got an interesting acronym: it is called EDGAR—which is regarded as one of the most elaborate, accessible, successful information databases on the globe, I am told by the Americans who designed it.
—Did they invent `EDGAR' and then fit the words to it?
—I do not know. I am sure means something like electronic data gathering and retrieval—how does that sound? Anyway, the Yanks say that it is a very good database. I am sure that the Australian Securities Commission would argue that theirs is even better, I am sure that the information technology industry thinks that they could come up with something better if you could pay them a few million dollars, and I am sure that, with the year 2000 approaching, EDGAR will have to be reinvented and improved for the new millennium.
That is the problem with foreign disclosure. I think that the broad concept is not such a bad one, except that it does create unnecessary paperwork. It is not as simple, as Senator Conroy said this morning, as basically folding an envelope and sticking a stamp on some letters to some Australian shareholders. If you have to report something, you are actually requiring that information to be put in the annual reports. Of course, the information that is available through EDGAR or through the foreign bourses' data information and retrieval systems, be it in Europe or in the Unites States—the two main places where Australian companies list—or in Canada, for example, that is available instantaneously if you need it.
The requirement of this amendment, as I understand it, is that it be put in the annual report. That would mean that the Australian shareholders would get that information up to eight months after the event occurred or after that disclosure was made, whereas, if they accessed it through the Internet or other electronic means, they could get it instantaneously. So we think that is the concern. The 
 government is strongly opposed to this amendment. On the environmental law, I simply say that we believe strongly that the requirements of compliance with environmental law should be in environmental laws and not in the Corporations Law.
In relation to the management discussion and analysis, again, I focused on that in the second reading debate, and I suggest that the approach that has been agreed by the Australian Stock Exchange be allowed to work. I do not know whether they have written to all people contributing to this debate, but I would be very happy, with the leave of the Senate, to incorporate in the Hansard letters that I have received, including one from the Managing Director of the Stock Exchange, Richard Humphry, who has outlined how they will be going about bringing in MD&A.
I might just quote from that letter. It says that a working group has already been established. In fact, prior to the government's discussions on this matter, a working group was established with members of the Group of 100—for the information of the Senate, that is a group made up of the financial controllers and directors of the top 100 companies in Australia. The Group of 100 has been the strongest advocate of MD&As. It is on this working group, as is the ASX, the Institute of Company Directors, the Business Council, both of the accounting bodies, and the Securities Institute. The working group is working on a best practice guide, to be completed by the end of September, which will be incorporated under ASX listing rule 4.10.3.
The letter goes on in some detail. They were going to do an annual review of that. I suggested to Mr Humphry and to others interested in this that it would be good to do a detailed and open public examination and report on the level of compliance with this best practice under listing rule 4.10.3 and to make a public report. I would be very happy if it were possible to get the agreement of the Senate to keep the MD&A out of federal law and allow it to operate through the self-regulatory organisational level of the Stock Exchange to ensure that that report was made at least to the Treasurer and that the Treasurer 
 would undertake to table that report—not that I can commit the Treasurer to do that, but I would be certain that the Treasurer would not be opposed to doing that.
I will therefore seek leave to incorporate that letter from Richard Humphry; a letter from IFSA, the Investment and Financial Services Association, again, strong proponents of MD&As who are pleased to see it going into the ASX rules rather than federal law; a letter from Bryce Denison, the National President of the Group of 100, saying that they are working constructively with the ASX to develop the best practice guide and that they see this as the appropriate way to proceed as opposed to seeking that it be put in the law; and, finally, the letter which has been quoted from extensively by Senator Sherry and others from the Securities Institute of Australia, which is making it quite clear that they would like to see it in the listing rules but would like to see it reviewed.
The government would like to see it reviewed. We want to see it reported on. We would like to see a report from the Stock Exchange on compliance. We would like to see it as a matter of national debate. The threat hangs over these organisations that, if they do not make MD&As work through a self-regulatory way, the threat of federal legislation hangs over them. I think very few people in industry, particularly shareholder groups, would regard that the way that it is being proceeded with through the Stock Exchange mechanism is far more desirable than that proposed by the Democrat amendment. I seek leave to incorporate those documents in Hansard.
Leave granted.

With this in mind, if the Listing Rules provide for MD&A, we do not believe it is necessary at this stage to include a legislative requirement in the Corporations Law. name: Campbell, Sen Ian
text:
—The concept of a management discussion and analysis is a narrative report on the prospects of the company, which many successful Australian companies already put in annual reports but many do not. A lot of corporate governance experts believe it is a very useful guide to shareholders about the future prospects of a company. The proposal here is to make it a mandatory requirement for all large Australian companies. By `large' I do not mean big listed companies; I mean virtually everyone who has more than 50 members. I think that is the small/large test. This would apply to basically every reporting entity. Everyone who has to write an annual report would be required to put this in. So it would affect a lot of small and medium sized businesses.
I think the Labor amendment, from memory, might restrict it to listed companies, which is obviously better. But the approach that we have pursued—firstly, in my rhetoric and, secondly, in the policy statements I have made on behalf of the government—is that the industry should be pushing these.
We should have groups, such as the Group of 100, company directors and the IFSA, preceded by AIMA, encouraging the use of MD&As. The Stock Exchange, in response to that encouragement some months ago, Senator Harradine—through you, Mr Chairman—pulled together a working group of those sorts of groups that I have mentioned, with a view to forming a set of best practice guidelines to be incorporated under one of the ASX listing rules; 4(10)(iii) is the specific listing rule.
Subsequent to forming that working group, the ASX has made a commitment to me in writing—which I have just incorporated in the Hansard—stating that it will incorporate this best practice guide and it will be reviewing it. I have asked the ASX, and it has agreed, to undertake an inquiry and make a report on the level of compliance with the requirement to do an MD&A and the effectiveness of it. In other words, is it actually improving corporate 
 governance, is it helping shareholders make decisions and is it helping with the governance of our corporations? The ASX has stated that it will make that report, and make it a public report after two years of operation.	 We think that is a very commendable approach.
There is no doubt that out there in the ether there is this strong threat of federal imposition of MD&A, and the reality of that is that we are sitting here in the Senate, talking about it right now—and they are cognisant of that. So there is a strong incentive for them to make it work, and there is a strong incentive for companies to have a serious look at making MD&As a part of their normal reporting process.
The value of having it done through listing rules and having groups like the G100, the accounting bodies and the Securities Institute—who, again, are very strong supporters of an MD&A—oversighting it is that they can adjust the requirement in the listing rules. If after the first year of annual reports it is proved that the way the listing rule is framed it is not producing the results or that people are confused about it, then the flexibility exists for this working group to alter the listing rule to make it more sensible, make it more understandable, make it more effective. That is the benefit of it—it could be changed every six months, it could be changed every three months. We think that is a much more effective way to travel on MD&As.

name: Murray, Sen Andrew
text:
—I would respond to Senator Harradine. The management discussion and analysis section of annual reports has been around as an issue for quite some time. It was the second Corporate Law Simplification Bill 1996 report from the joint committee which recommended that there should be an MD&A, as it is called, of the matters that members need to be informed on if they are to understand the overall financial position of the company.
The parliamentary secretary is quite right in indicating that things have moved on, and the ASX is now in a position to present and to recommend a listing section. However, it is not true that there is universal acceptance of 
 ASX's proposal, even though that is strongly advocated by it and strongly supported by some bodies. We did, in the most recent hearing, have a number of organisations—including the Australian Accounting Research Foundation—which felt that the MD&A was necessary in the bill; in particular, they felt it was necessary because it is a characteristic of major capital markets, such as the United States, the United Kingdom and Canada.
The point that the parliamentary secretary is making is that the professional bodies all do agree that there should be an MD&A, and so does the ASX, but they want it to be voluntary. As I understand it, the ASX has made it clear that it is not a requirement to include MD&A, but its listings guide would be a matter of guidance. That is what concerns me, because it is my belief that an MD&A should be obligatory. It is vital that shareholders receive a minimum checklist of information required. That laid out in my amendment item 38, Senator Harradine, comes out of the deliberations of the joint committee—it is not something I have invented—and has wide support.
If the bill had said, `Look, either you must have an MD&A of this kind, or you must do the ASX's listing,' I would have been more inclined to the parliamentary secretary's view. But it does not do that; it leaves it open, unless the ASX listing is abided with by the company. Where Senator Cook's amendment goes is to limit the MD&A only to publicly listed companies, whereas the MD&A requirement we have put is to a company of a certain size and up.
That is a legitimate debate, but I have never understood why corporate entities of 50 or more should not still have to provide fundamental material, such as results of operations, key strategic initiatives and major commitments to their shareholders—even if it is 50 people. So, if you like, I take a fairly maximalist view, the Labor Party takes a view in between and the government takes a fairly flexible and open market view.
Once again, it is a case of there being good arguments on a number of sides. But, at this juncture, I am not persuaded that the lack of 
 an MD&A would not result in some problems for shareholders in the nature of reporting.
—The question is that amendments 35 and 36 be agreed to.
Question resolved in the negative.
—I now propose that we consider Democrats amendment No. 37.

name: Cook, Sen Peter
text:
—I have been sitting here listening to the ebb and flow of this discussion, but it is about time I came out of the closet and declared where I stand on some of these things. We did not support amendments 35 and 36 moved by the Democrats because we have got our own amendment No. 7 which we think covers that situation. We share with Senator Harradine, who raised the question about Democrat amendment 37 being dealt with separately, agreement that it should be dealt with separately. But on Democrat amendment No. 37 I would like to hear a little more argument, if I may.
Let me indicate our view. In principle we can accept that amendment, but I am not sure that I understand the practical application of it. It is on the point of how practically it would operate that I would appreciate a little more background. It might be that we would therefore want to more explicitly word the amendment. Let me tell you what my problem is. Firstly, the idea of companies reporting about significant environmental regulation in their reports is an appropriate thing, we think. It would seem to me that what is being required here relates to a significant or a particular environmental regulation. I am not quite sure how you define `significant', though I am pretty sure how you might define `particular'. Leaving that aside for the moment, the details of the company's performance in relation to that regulation would be set out. This is self-assessment, I assume, in that they would set out in their report what the regulation was and describe in the first person for themselves how they believe they have performed up against that regulation.
—What happens if they don't?
—Senator Campbell, you can ask your question when it is your turn.
—Let me take the interjection, through you, Mr Temporary Chairman, because it does help the debate. What happens if they do not do that or if they do not do that adequately, given all the MD&A emphasis we have put on this debate thus far. My problem is that I do not disagree with the idea but I am still looking for how it will actually work effectively. That is what I would appreciate some more words on. Moving to amendment 38—

name: Murray, Sen Andrew
text:
—Mr Temporary Chairman, we have three minutes left. Is that correct?
—That is correct.
—Perhaps we should just deal with No. 37 and clear that out of the way. We can come to No. 38 tomorrow when we resume the debate, if that is satisfactory with you, Senator Cook.
—Yes.
—I was informed primarily in my approach to this matter by the document I outlined earlier to the Senate, which is a very good document by the chartered accountants in Australia on the impact of environmental matters on the accountancy profession. Simply put, modern environmental law, where it is significant and material—I do not mean specifications to do with a scrubber and a stack—can result in substantial consequences to corporations. We think it is appropriate, and so do the accountants, that it is reported on. You picked up the words `particular' and `significant'. I too had that debate with the draftsperson who put this together. There are some difficulties with it. Again I would suggest, with the support of the parliamentary secretary, that if this was to go down this element should be referred to the committee for examination. I do not believe it has been examined fully before.

name: Campbell, Sen Ian
text:
—I indicate that I would be happy for the parliamentary committee to examine it. In principle, I would have thought that if there is an environmental regulator you would need to be responsible to that regulator.
Progress reported.

name: Abetz, Sen Eric
text:
—The decision by Labor and the Greens to block the proposed Wesley Vale pulp mill in my home state of Tasmania approximately a decade ago is now having horrendous social, environmental and economic consequences. The cheap political strategy of the time by Labor, in concert with the myopic Green movement, those 10 long years ago is unfortunately just a blur in the corporate memory of my fellow Tasmanians. But, as we consider the opportunities of the magnesite mine in Tasmania and other issues facing this nation, we need to reflect on and learn from the Wesley Vale experience.
As a direct result of the actions of Labor's environment minister, Senator Graham Richardson, and the Greens' Christine Milne, we have had in Canberra this week a delegation of workers struggling to keep their jobs—they and 200-plus of their fellow workers now face unemployment. What happened those 10 years ago? A proposal to build a world-class paper pulp mill at a cost of $1 billion was announced. Christine Milne, now the Leader of the Greens, made her public debut and launched her political career fighting the proposal. Aided and abetted by Labor, she won.
Senator Murphy interjecting—
—Senator Murphy seems to be proud of Labor's achievement in scuttling the Wesley Vale mill. I simply ask, at what price?
There are two devastating costs of this Labor-Greens victory. Firstly, environment 
 ally, the decision was a disaster. The mill would have processed timber from a  sustainable and environmentally friendly source. Further, the mill would have been a state-of-the-art plant, emitting minimal waste—less waste than all other comparable mills in the world. Remember the Greens' slogan? `Think globally, act locally'. They thought politically and acted selfishly, because by their actions they ensured the ongoing success of the mill elsewhere in the world, belching out its pollution. They preferred that to the clean mill which was proposed; they were hardly thinking globally. Further, the timber supply for other world pulp producers does not necessarily hail from a forest industry culture as meticulous and concerned about sustainable environmental practices as is Tasmania's.
The Burnie pulp mill has been struggling for a long time. It needed new plant and equipment. Amcor, unfortunately, have not seen their way clear to provide that necessary investment, and they have therefore decided to close the mill. I trust they will change their mind. If we had had Wesley Vale up and running we would at least be using Tasmanian product and manufactured pulp in Burnie for the production of paper. Instead, we now face the very real prospect that the Burnie paper mill will be using pulp made from the rainforests of Indonesia—where there is no forest practices code or regional forest agreement, where there is not 40 per cent of the land mass set aside for reserves, and where there are not comprehensive and adequate reserves as there are in Tasmania; not to mention reafforestation.
The Greens' actions will lead to extra market opportunities for Indonesia's rainforests and, ultimately, to their destruction. That is not a good environmental outcome, let alone a commonsense outcome. The Greens' lack of vision has allowed an old polluting mill to be favoured over a clean mill. Their lack of vision will now favour product from the unsustainable harvest of Indonesian rainforest over product from Tasmania's sustainable and well-regulated forests. Their actions are as environmentally destructive as they are socially and economically destructive. That is the second great cost of that 
 politically motivated and short-sighted decision of Labor and the Greens taken all those years ago.
For a small population of less than half a million people, a $1 billion investment would have been huge—in anyone's language. The benefits for jobs in construction, maintenance and supply would have had an ongoing, beneficial flow-through effect for our Tasmanian economy. The presence of such a mill would have been a great confidence boost to the people investing in the forest industry but, more importantly, it would have provided opportunities and security for the workers and their families and for local timber communities and towns. The potential benefits of all those jobs and of downstream processing were denied to our fellow Tasmanians. Their wellbeing was sacrificed on the altar of political expediency.
Instead of having a world-class pulp mill, we are watching the demise of Burnie's pulp mill and, more importantly, the loss of many jobs, which will undoubtedly have the devastating flow-on social consequences of bankruptcy, mortgagee sales and family breakdowns. What is tragic is that people like Christine Milne and Graham Richardson built their so-called political careers and notoriety on the back of a decision which they must have known would have this devastating social impact. The so-called victory was cheap; the cost was very expensive indeed. That type of irresponsible, short-term politicking has devastating long-term consequences.
I hope and pray that Tasmania will not be subjected to a similar campaign by Labor and the Greens on the proposed magnesite mine development in north-west Tasmania. The proposal is exciting and promises employment in a range of fields, together with real potential for downstream processing. Reject this magnesite mine proposal and you reject the aspirations of hundreds of Tasmanian workers and their families who desperately need employment opportunities. Reject this and you deny the state government desperately needed revenue for the provision of services to Tasmanians. Reject this and the prospect of another major development will be denied for 
 another decade—with all the devastating consequences that involves.
The effective and hardworking member for Braddon, Chris Miles, needs to be congratulated on his effective leadership on jobs. Under the previous Labor government, Amcor shed hundreds of jobs from its Burnie operations. Tioxide closed, with a loss of 200 jobs. What was Labor's response? Absolutely nothing. In stark contrast, after the recent announcement of job losses at Burnie's pulp mill, what did Chris Miles and the Liberal government do? Within 48 hours a cabinet subcommittee was in the city of Burnie, listening to the workers' and the community's concerns and aspirations. They are now preparing an assistance package—a response.
For the magnesite mine proposal, Chris Miles initiated a visit by Senator Parer, Minister for Resources and Energy, and organised a public meeting to form a support group for this exciting development. That sort of proactive, pro-jobs initiative of Chris Miles and this government is what government should be all about: helping workers, families and communities. In the Mersey-Lyell region, which covers the electorate of Braddon, the employment trend collapsed by 11 per cent under Labor between 1989 and 1996. It is now rebuilding at six per cent and that is a substantial rate, but Chris Miles, our Tasmanian colleagues and I realise it needs to be increased.
As the Tasmanian delegation which is here fights for jobs and a future—a fight which I fully support—it is important to cast a backward glance and remind ourselves what necessitated their visit. I trust the workers, their families and communities will understand that today's problems are the product of the Labor and Greens collusion those 10 years ago.
Could I invite the workers and their families to help Labor and the Greens to understand their rejection of those tactics by rejecting Labor and the Greens at the next election? Job opportunities are the top priority for me, as they are for Chris Miles and my Liberal colleagues. Yet the alternative government hardly raises the issue of employment in question time or in public debate. Their 
 record is appalling. After two years in opposition they find themselves without a jobs policy.
On the other hand, the Liberal government is unapologetically pro-jobs. Our regret is that we predicted the social and economic consequences of the scuttling of the Wesley Vale mill and, unfortunately, we were unable to save it. Nevertheless, we will stand shoulder-to-shoulder with those who face the loss of jobs. Having said that, we are looking forward to, and will actively promote, the saving of jobs and the creation of new opportunities that the magnasite mine proposal provides.
